pagedescription: In Norway, obtaining a visa or other immigration documents depends on the purpose of your stay and your nationality.

visa.details: A Schengen Visa allows you to stay in Norway or other Schengen countries for up to 90 days within a 180-day period for purposes such as tourism, business, or family visits.

toggle2.showtext: How long do I have to wait?

temp_res.details: If you plan to stay in Norway for more than 90 days, you will likely need a residence permit rather than a visa. Common reasons for applying for a residence permit include work, study, or family reunification.

toggle1.details: If you have a job offer in Norway, your employer may apply for a work permit on your behalf, or you can apply yourself.

toggle2.details: If youâ€™ve been accepted into a Norwegian educational institution, you can apply for a student residence permit.

toggle3.details: If you have family members in Norway (e.g., a spouse, registered partner, or cohabitant), you may apply for family reunification.

perm_res.details: After living in Norway for a certain number of years on a valid residence permit, you can apply for permanent residence (usually after 3-5 years, depending on your situation).
